node.text: Burgundy’s labels are decorative, even iconic; but they’re also a fascinating window onto the region’s social history. In this short video @wgfkelley explains why famous and little-heard-of producers share a label, and how this reminds us on the domaine bottling movement’s origins.

node.text: In the final part of the Burgundian Vignoble series @wgfkelley looks below the surface, at the drains and even cisterns that lie beneath the surface of some #Burgundian #vineyards, influencing their capacity to retain water or to remove an excess. He's seen eleventh-century cisterns in the Mâconnais, but this especially impressive example in the Côte de Nuits is around a century old. Burgundy is full of surprises!

node.title: Constructing the Burgundian Vignoble: Cisterns & Drains (Part 3 of 3)

node.text: In this video by @wgfkelley explains how powerful machinery came onto the scene in the late 20th century. Not only were murgers demolished and contours smoothed, but land previously unsuitable for planting was reclaimed. The commune of Meursault was a pioneer of this, using heavy machinery to pulverize stones in the Chaumes de Narvaux, Casse Têtes and Perrières. This new vineyard land was leased to young growers by the commune. Today, rather than removing stones by hand prior to replanting, it’s more and more common to see growers choosing to break up rocks mechanically and recontour their vineyards, which has consequences for soil structure. It’s another reminder that the Burgundian vignoble is a man made landscape...

node.title: Constructing the Burgundian Vignoble: Heavy Machinery (Part 2 of 3)

node.text: The #Burgundian landscape has been planted to vines for so long that it’s easy to forget that creating a #vineyard is often more complicated than merely planting vines. In this short video @wgfkelley discusses how, over the centuries, rocks were removed to build « murgers », create soils and smooth contours. Including a cameo by William's flower-gathering three year old daughter 🤣

node.title: Constructing the Burgundian Vignoble: The Landscape (Part 1 of 3)

node.text: In this short video, Emmanuel Guillot of @guillotbroux talks about restoring and replanting the abandoned walled #vineyards of Cruzille, overtaken by the forest in the aftermath of #phylloxera. A labor of love for future generations!

node.text: During a fascinating vertical tasting with @domainejmvincent we took time to visit the vineyards, including Jean-Marc’s high density plantings of #Chardonnay at the northern end of Les Gravières (where the soils are white marl, unlike the rest of this large climat). This domaine is one of @wgfkelley's favorites in Burgundy, and the 2019s are their best wines to date! But more about that soon in the pages of @wine_advocate

node.title: Jean-Marc Vincent on his high density plantings in Santenay

node.text: 🔊 SOUND ON: In this video, our #Champagne reviewer @wgfkelley discuss how Champagne ages - as well as how its aging trajectory differs from other wines - while opening a 1964 Royale Réserve from Philipponnat.

node.text: @michelebernetti brings us inside Marche and Abruzzo, two regions farmed by @umanironchi. Verdicchio and Montepulciano are discussed, and how did the Pecorino grape really get its name? This and more. Enjoy 🇮🇹 🍷

node.text: Castellina, Chianti Classico, Sangiovese, Maremma, LOVE ❤️ ART 🖼 and WINE 🍷 are topics of conversation with @fattorianittardi Léon Femfert.

node.title: @monicalarner chats with Léon Femfert of the beautiful @fattorianittardi

node.accessibility_caption: Photo shared by Robert Parker Wine Advocate on July 23, 2021 tagging @milltonvineyards. May be an image of 1 person, outdoors and text.

node.text:
Robert Parker Green Emblem Recipient - Milton Vineyards & Winery, Gisborne, New Zealand.⁣
⁣⁣
⁣Since the very beginnings of the Millton story in 1984, the family has thought of themselves as stewards of the land. Working in one of New Zealand’s warmest and wettest viticultural regions, the family nevertheless pursued organic and—later—biodynamic agriculture with a view toward sustainability. ⁣
⁣⁣
⁣In 1989, Millton was the first producer in New Zealand to attain BioGro certification for organic wine production. As such pioneers, James and Annie Millton have been instrumental in demonstrating the benefits of these practices to like-minded producers.⁣
⁣⁣
⁣More info via our bio link.⁣
⁣⁣
⁣📸: @milltonvineyards

node.text:
RECENTLY PUBLISHED: Italy, Umbria: Recent Releases from Montefalco.⁣
⁣⁣
⁣Umbria is the verdant, landlocked heart of Central Italy and the only Italian region without access to the sea or international borders. Its soulful and sometimes introspective personality translates to the many, varied wines made in the region, many of which are faithful expressions of local indigenous grapes.⁣
⁣⁣
⁣Read @monicalarner's full report and 110+ tasting notes via link in bio. ⁣
⁣⁣
⁣📸: @arnaldocaprai & @monicalarner

node.text:
RECENTLY PUBLISHED: Italy, Tuscany, Montalcino: The 2013 and 1983 Biondi-Santi Brunello di Montalcino Riservas. ⁣
⁣⁣
⁣This little article focuses on two wines from the winery’s historic library. The 2013 Brunello di Montalcino Riserva is a current release, and the 1983 Brunello di Montalcino Riserva is part of the estate’s late-release program. Both wines show stunning freshness and depth, a reminder of the slightly cooler conditions seen in both years. Sangiovese loves a long and steady growing season without weather extremes for slow ripening and a late harvest. That’s exactly what it got in both 2013 and 1983. The stunning detail and acidity shown by both these wines is what will guide them over the course of their respective bottle evolutions.⁣
⁣⁣
⁣Read @monicalarner’s full report and tasting notes via link in bio. ⁣
⁣⁣
⁣📸 : @biondisantigreppo

node.text:
Robert Parker Green Emblem Recipient - Alois Lageder, Alto Adige, Italy

A successful model for biodynamic farming was introduced to Italy thanks in large measure to Alois Lageder and his forward-thinking family. He was not the first to practice this philosophy, but Alois Lageder showed that biodynamics could be scalable and applied across 55 hectares of vines and a network of farming partners. His carefully studied efforts started with research in the 1990s, and by 2004, he had completely abandoned conventional agriculture, converting entirely to a farming method that seeks a holistic balance between humans, plants, animals and the cosmos.

More info via our bio link.

📷: Alois Lageder

node.text:
RECENTLY PUBLISHED: France, Burgundy: Insiders’ Burgundy – The Côte Chalonnaise, Hautes-Côtes & Lesser-Known Appellations of the Côte D'Or. ⁣
⁣⁣
⁣This report once again unites disparate subregions that share at least one common characteristic: they have all been the victim of a vicious cycle, whereby negative consumer perceptions impose low prices, encouraging producers to privilege quantity and cash flow over quality, resulting in mediocre wines that reinforce those negative perceptions. Historically, when excellent wine did emerge from such places, it was traded under a more famous and glamorous name: one of Mercurey’s best producers tells how his 1999, bought by a négociant from the Côte d’Or, was bottled and sold as “Pommard.” ⁣
⁣⁣
⁣Read @wgfkelley's full report and 340 tasting notes via link in bio. ⁣
⁣⁣
⁣📸 : @domainefaiveley

node.text:
Robert Parker Green Emblem Recipient - Tasca d'Almerita, Sicily, Italy⁣
⁣⁣
⁣Sicily, the sun-soaked island at the heart of the Mediterranean, has always enjoyed a healthy tendency toward independence and out-of-the-box thinking. It is the first Italian region to develop an integrated sustainability protocol for wineries, with a 10-point action plan, a scientific committee for oversight and a certification logo that wineries can print on their bottles. The program is called SOStain (Save our Soils), and it was launched in 2010 by the Tasca d’Almerita family, one of the oldest and most celebrated winemaking families on the island.⁣
⁣⁣
⁣More info via our bio link.⁣
⁣⁣
⁣📸: @tascadalmerita

node.text:
RECENTLY PUBLISHED: France, Burgundy: Domaine Duroché’s Latricières-Chambertin, 2010-2019.⁣
⁣⁣
⁣In recent years, Domaine Duroché has rapidly ascended into the ranks of Burgundy’s most highly allocated producers. The wines are harder and harder to find in the context of insatiable globalized demand for the Côte d’Or’s wines. But for all the domaine’s newfound celebrity, its history, methods and evolution over time remain comparatively sparsely reported. This vertical tasting of the estate’s elusive Latricières-Chambertin provided the opportunity to delve into the details. ⁣
⁣⁣
⁣Read @wgfkelley’s full report and tasting notes via link in bio. ⁣
⁣📸: @wgfkelley

node.text:
Robert Parker Green Emblem Recipient - Salcheto, Tuscany, Italy

At the heart of the Vino Nobile di Montepulciano appellation in one of the most beautiful corners of Tuscany, Salcheto is as pure and green as its stunning surroundings. Salcheto claims to be the first winery in the world to have certified the carbon footprint of a bottle of wine (according to ISO 14064 standard, in 2010). Thanks to a joint study with the Università di Siena, Salcheto calculated that each 750-milliliter bottle of wine it produces is equal to 1.83 kilograms of carbon dioxide emissions. Once the winery was able to quantify its carbon footprint, it did everything in its power to eliminate it. The Salcheto Carbon Free initiative focuses on neutralizing CO2 emissions from production (which account for nearly half of the total), the 38% from the packaging and the 26% from transportation.

⁣More info via link in our bio.⁣⁣

📸: @salcheto

node.text:
RECENTLY PUBLISHED: USA, Washington State: Spotlight on Walla Walla Valley. ⁣
⁣⁣
⁣The Walla Walla Valley is slightly greener and lusher than most of the Columbia Valley, where it is nestled in eastern Washington with its proximity to the Blue Mountains to the east and sloping hills all around. Notorious for having a higher pH, the wines of Walla Walla Valley offer a delightful and youthful approachability yet possess the capacity to age with grace. While Cabernet Sauvignon remains the most planted wine grape in the Walla Walla Valley, Syrah and Grenache show incredible promise, as a slurry of new plantings capture more producer’s eyes and more consumer palates.⁣
⁣⁣
⁣Read @sommelieranthonymueller's full report and 210+ tasting notes via link in bio. ⁣
⁣⁣
⁣📸: @sommelieranthonymueller

node.text:
Robert Parker Green Emblem Recipient - Weingut Odinstal, Pfalz, Germany⁣
⁣⁣
⁣There are few wineries in Germany that are run with the same seriousness and consistency, sustainably organic and biodynamic in Steiner's sense, as the Demeter-certified Odinstal Estate. Andreas Schumann has long been highly regarded not only as a farmer and winemaker but is also in demand internationally as a viticultural consultant. He is well connected in biodynamic circles far beyond the country's borders and creates new networks as a lecturer as well as an instructor on his own farm, which, by the way, is heated purely with wood and pellets.⁣
⁣⁣
⁣⁣More info via link in our bio.⁣⁣⁣
⁣⁣
⁣📸: @weingut_odinstal
